properties.name: Chipping Norton - b1967-1971
properties.description: Posted by Alanf  chipping nortonIt\'s bright out. The garden is big to me, huge in fact; a kingdom. And me and Nan are doing magic things by the red brick wall. Nan is old and wrinkled, still energetic, but so old. As old then as I see her today. And even then, as she was looking after me, I was watching after her with all the bravado of a 4 year old. She is wearing some old, indistinct clothes. All I really remember are the black rubber boots, so large they almost fall off in the mud, not hers. They\'re dull and pale beside my bright yellow, snug pair. But she wades into the mud anyway, bending and scooping, placing and covering. One potato done. "That\'s easy, I can do that, Nan." So we plant. And, while we work with our hands, my mind jumps ahead to the bushes and trees that will be here soon, all because we are doing this. "How long does it take, Nan?" I don\'t remember what she said, it didn\'t matter. Time was still outside of me. It shifted and bucked against my attempts to control it. Boring minutes would be hours and summer days slipped by in eye blinks. They still seem to do that, but when you\'re four they do, absolutely and devastatingly. There were no trees the next day, no harvest to bring home from my kingdom. Mum would have to get her potatoes from wherever it was that she always got them from. Now that I think about it, where were Mum\'s potato trees and why did we need more?

properties.name: Edinburgh - 1993
properties.description: Posted by AlanfDusk is bleeding the blue from the sky and our electric lights gamely take on the long night. But The Grand spotlights itself with self-importance, transforms itself from the dowdy Victorian monolith into the star of the boardwalk. As though the spotlights were really sacrificial bonfires, the smell of meat and poultry escapes the basement restaurant, wraps itself around the grounds, inviting and reassuring, calling in the faithful. In come the priests at their costumed best, with native headdresses and ceremonial sceptres (nee umbrellas) and the priestesses wearing pearls like smiles around their necks, diamonds like tears upon their fingers and lobes. In circles and groups they chant and pray, driven by smell of flesh and the blood-red wine and the dance of the wait staff. Their song hums accompaniment with the drums and then turns and toys with the beat and drives over it and under and all around it, calling to the kitchens and the dance floor. The windows rattle as it taps them, searching it\'s way out into the night, bone-dry black, choking in dust and city fumes.

properties.name: Leeds - 1993
properties.description: Posted by AlanfLeeds is a typical northern town: industrial, no-nonsense, straight-ahead. Blunt in fact. The streets are drab with a sameness that chills me at every new corner. The soot that thins the sunlight, is an edge on the air. The people are no different from city people anywhere. They seem happy in their world - no matter that tomorrow will be cold and grey again. To Chris this is all new and the novelty captivates her. It\'s like a winter wonderland, only the snow is dust. To me it\'s London and Boston reinvented, the same rhythms masked by a similar tune. I don\'t want to sour her fun, but soon my mind is a few hundred miles south of here. I grew up down there. Paignton is not Leeds, but still I\'m afraid it might be. Afraid that, by the mere association of being in the same country, my almost picture perfect hometown won\'t be there anymore. How long are the winters there now, how crowded are the beaches this year? Does the air still hold an honest sea-salt smell, are the parks still green? Can it really be untouched by whomever it is that builds cities like Leeds? I\'m too afraid to go look, too sad to tell Chris in her excitement.

properties.name: New York - 1980
properties.description: Posted by Alanfcentral parkHis death was not a body thing for it was his body that he left. Now, there\'s a solemn corner of New York State that blooms each year. Under cold December slate, mourners mouth cherished words that chanced open valves to peace and hope in his lemon juice world. Because he sang to them in their voices disguised as his, It\'s him they most miss in the widowed years and shallow days of dreams that fade as the dreamer fades. His words taste brittle, painted on the lips of strangers and living only in short sun days, his followers starve on the afterimages of imagination. Trodden down by the sweeping blindness of legal right, the swaying mob concludes a concert in the candlelight park, an island in the nightmare he would have better lived to fight. An end to the annual mass of a modern saint, desperate man, who deserved a better fate.

properties.name: Paignton - 1971 - 1979
properties.description: Posted by AlanfWhere is home? Home is where the heart is. But where is home? Home is the town I grew up in, well, the formative years. It\'s a comfortable place with warm summer days at the beach and mud-wonderful football Saturday mornings. It\'s school chums and park games and back alley cricket. It\'s the place you see in photo albums: black and white, faded, silent snapshots of awkward kids with freckles and missing teeth and braces and baggy shorts and teddy hanging from one leg and goggle glasses and wet hair from running through the sprinkler and it\'s just the way you remember it. Only it\'s not. It\'s the place where bag ladies scour the beach for returnable bottles left by careless tourists. It\'s the place where the police come at 3 a.m. to arrest the drug addict across the street and all the neighbours come out in pyjamas and housecoats to watch. It\'s the place where children get snatched off the street and sirens announce another arson. This is home in full colour and stereo sound. But I was a kid before; I guess that makes all the difference.

properties.name: Port Credit - 1989 - 1994
properties.description: Posted by Alanfport credit, ontarioMy moon sits hard over a midnight blue horizon, etched in a lover\'s eyes, shattered pyramid on the neap tide\'s height, sentenced to death by a shepherd sunrise. Lonely, it whirls in an arc of sadness that is my sky, torn from the wild geese throats and tired waves that carve, pitiless, man\'s shores. Never to own, lunar our lease shines, envy breeds disciple in it\'s garden hovels, siren song to the senseless hordes. Pray, dream, wish me past this cure of sullen days, so, as you bind me in lilac chords, mummified, enslaved, man in the moon night sings, sings gangrene curdled in fallen flight.

properties.name: Scarborough - 1993
properties.description: Posted by Alanf"I think that it\'s time," you said, "past time that I should be going," you said and then smiled. My fingers felt for warmth on your beautiful blue lips, then, when they fell, my eyes remembered the fever of your smiles. "What are you thinking now," you said when I shook my head no, "you mustn\'t do this to us" you said. "Don\'t think of me this way" you said, as you bent to take my head in your arms. Your fragile heart filled the close, dark confines of my world. It raced to muffle your soothing words and lingered as you retired in tears. "Goodbye," you said as you went, and my goodbye would have bounced harmlessly off the back of a closing door, so I left the word unspoken, where it would shiver in my head.

properties.name: Toronto - 1986
properties.description: Posted by AlanfHis Word is on the streets and the Word is currency. Modesty is over with, we want Triple XXXtasy. Judgment Day means parole, the price of democracy. Deliverance now means pizza, thirty minutes or free. And Faith\'s a scary thing that works the corner of Jane and Three.

properties.name: Waterloo - 1991
properties.description: Posted by AlanfA short forever ago, an invitation was laid before me. And, with rare audacity, my arm accepted for both to know. Now, as then, who could argue that less than right was done. Neither you or I would entertain that thought. For now, each moment stands separate and whole alone, a little more added to a sum of one and one makes one.
